title: Wednesday, 19th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:11 am
BE11:11am

I'm starting late because there's nothing happening.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Morning all
SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all
Soundbuy Same this side.........
BE11:11am

Well, nothing much.

Excel Developer On a news diet
BE11:11am

Apart from this: https://www.ft.com...-8274-55b72926558f

Waterloo Morning punctilious ones
Markkus Morning
Blank canvas Babcock?
Excel Developer Inflation breaks higher, that's newsworthy
11:12 am
BE11:13am

€200bn!

BE11:13am

Danske Bank’s chief executive has resigned after Denmark’s biggest lender said about €200bn in questionable money flowed through its Estonian branch in one of the largest money laundering scandals ever seen.

Denmark’s largest bank said “a series of major deficiencies” in its control and governance system allowed its Estonian branch to be used for suspicious transactions from 2007 until 2015.

Danske said about €200bn of payments had flowed through its Estonian branch from non-resident customers — from countries such as Russia, the UK and the British Virgin Islands — but that it could not yet estimate how many of these were suspicious.

An analysis of 6,200 of the riskiest customers — out of 15,000 non-resident clients in total — showed that the “vast majority have been found to be suspicious”.

Airborne Cigar billion here, billion there, soon you're talking real money...
Soundbuy SSP Group - anybody pushing this am. Quick out the blocks and +3.5%
BE11:13am

You'll remember a figure of $150bn was reported a while back

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And we still don't have a specific number.

Soundbuy .........or Autogrill getting a mention again...........
BE11:14am

What we don't have is a CEO. Borgen's off.

Manxish Morning each
BE11:15am

Full report's here, if you want it: https://danskebank...branch-.-la=en.pdf

Flaneur I bet Borgen will be getting a handsome payoff too...
Airborne Cigar @BE - considering it seems to have been Borgen's baby, wasn't much else he could have done, was there? Unless he wanted to wait to be pushed...
11:15 am
BE11:15am

We also get a small profit warning to cover a DKr1.5bn donation as well as weak trading.

BE11:16am

Have Citi to summarise where we are.

BE11:16am

On the positive side: 1) FY18 net profit outlook has remained as expected (DKr 16-17bn incl. DKr 1.5bn Q3 donation), 2) no change to the buyback, 3) no sanctions violations so far, and 4) no mention of US authorities. On the negative side: 1) total transactions number is large (€200bn) with a large proportion deemed suspicious (although not necessarily illegal), 2) CEO is leaving, although this was expected and he is staying on until a successor is found), and 3) investigation is still ongoing – need to complete customer and sanctions checks, and we await further information from the US.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

I'll also use their report summary, for ease.

VV75 morning
BE11:17am

So far c6.2k customers (almost all from the c10k NRP customers) have been examined, with the vast majority being deemed suspicious. Although the report notes that not all payments from individual customers would be deemed suspicious. Although this does not implicate illegal activity, just that it should have been reported. On legality, the report notes that “Ascertaining whether this is the case typically requires more information than is possessed by a financial institution”. There is no accurate estimate of the total suspicious transactions, although “It is expected that a large part of the payments were suspicious”. Historically the Estonian branch filed SARs on 653 customers in the NRP (the Estonian branch filed SARs on 760 customers when including the additional 5,000 customers also subject to investigation).

anonymous254 Silly question but what does "flow through" actually mean? Money flowing into accounts held at Danske? Report kindly provided here by BE says they had independent IT system, but surely if flowing into actual accounts it would appear?
BE11:17am

Is it in the price tho? Maybe, Jefferies says.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The shares currently price in CoE of 15% (+7ppts vs. Nordic peers).
In market share terms, accounting for the FY17 dividend (DKK 9.4bn) + leaving aside the buyback (64% of DKK 10bn completed so far), the loss has totaled DKK 60bn. Revenue perf. has been weak at Danske YTD, driven by trading (3 consecutive quarters of under-perf.) – FY18 top-line cons. has fallen c.DKK 3bn, with trading 73% of this (’19 revs have fallen DKK 2.2bn, 71% of which is trading). While cost estimates have risen DKK 1.4 bn for ‘18 (reflecting some of the AML gross proceeds ‘donation’), this is offset by ongoing impairment writebacks. Using Danske’s 5-YR avg. 1-YR fwd P/E of c.10x as a guide (+ tax @ 23%), this indicates cDKK 24bn of market cap loss from earnings – implying cDKK 36bn (US$ 5.6bn) has potentially been wiped out owing to the AML. This amount may not necessarily be linked to a potential fine – while Danske have noted ’18 should be the peak for expenses linked to the investigation (c5% of the workforce have been dealing with this), cost estimates have risen by 2% YTD for ’19, as the street speculates over increased BAU compliance spend + a regulatory monitor. A fine (+ reduced earnings power) has consequences for capital return, & FY18-19 buyback estimates have fallen DKK 2bn YTD.

Flaneur @anon254 - thats the sort of question that brings a knock on your front door...
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good morning all.
anonymous254 ahh, sorry, is in the report later on: ("Funds transferred from external parties to customers in the Non-Resident Portfolio and subsequently transferred from such customers to external recipients are referred to as “the flow”)". Surprised even with separate IT system in Estonian branch they weren't having some sort of reporting of customer deposits. Maybe I'm too naive though.
Tom Dalgleish Will the Yanks fine them?
BE11:21am

Handling dirty money seems to be a risk that banks have to wear simply to operate. The problem here seems to be that Danske was too blasé about it.

BE11:22am

In terms of the risk of a US fine .... note the "no findings of sanctions violations" line in the report.

Pharma @Tom, no dollars involved, no interaction with the US financial system - of course they will fine them.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

There had been questions about Danske's link with North Korea

BE11:23am

Which seems to have been stopped at branch level

BE11:23am

All in all, we're probably not in US/OFAC investigation territory. Maybe.

SSP mentioned.

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 725.57, up 24.07 (+3.43%), High: 726.30, Low: 709.40, Volume: 319.48k
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Nothing exciting. Just a UBS upgrade.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Note the source of said dodgy money: UK & BVI! When will we become clean, if ever?
Soundbuy Ahh...............ta.......
BE11:25am

We review the growth and margin outlook for SSP, with our analysis highlighting the potential for further margin improvement, whilst the current outlook in airports is also supportive of top-line growth. On margins, we believe upside is supported by historical evidence of company delivering ahead of expectations and ongoing management initiatives on gross margin and labour costs, which have proved successful to date. With the shares currently trading on 17.3x N12M EV/EBIT (vs 17.5x over the last 12months) we believe the ongoing margin opportunity is largely priced in already, however we see operational momentum supporting the current valuation and upgrade to Neutral.

Blank canvas As we are dealing with Danske, it's worth remembering that today is International Talk Like a Pirate Day
BE11:26am

Management guides convervatively on margins and charges upwards of £5 for a stale cheese and ham baguette. That's the gist of it.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Also, air travel's looking okay .....

BE11:26am

Air passenger traffic outlook remains strong and Diio data confirms continued good growth in air passenger capacity over the short term in SSP's regions. We remain cautious about the outlook for rail in the UK given current level of passenger growth and potential lifestyle changes. Contract wins were particularly strong in 2017 with this expected to continue in 2018, but slowdown thereafter, however we see upside risk to our numbers given the recent level of contract wins.

Flaneur @1st Lt - what was the destination though?
BE11:27am

So it's at fair value or thereabouts, says UBS.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We value SSP on 17.3x EV/EBIT 2019e (from 16.5x EV/EBIT 2018e) broadly in line with the average last 12m (c17.5x 12m forward EV/EBIT) and also represent a premium to peers in line with history, which we believe is justified given historic conservatism of management and upside potential to UBS and consensus estimates.

CPI inflation goes from 2.5% to 2.7% against a consensus of 2.4%

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I'm 1st Lt. Fletcher Christian - not a pirate, just behaved like one for a while! ;)
XYZed @ Pharma FWIW, looks like were dollars "As for the approximately 10,000 customers in the Non-Resident Portfolio from 2007 through 2015, there were payments in 32 different currencies, the majority of the total amounts being in USD and EUR. "

11:31 am

BE11:31am

Well, higher theatre ticket prices did.

Airborne Cigar @anon254 - if Danske is anything like some large international banks of my aquaintance, Head Office has historically had no idea what business goes through the foreign branches - the reporting is on the P&L level. Made implementing Liquidity Reporting regimes challenging, so probable better now than it was, but don't assume anyone outside Tallinn gave a s**t about the details...
BE11:31am

As did transport fares.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

And clothes nudged higher too.

M2 Any news on Berkeley Group Holdings ??
BE11:33am

Want someone to say it was summer so it's too early to tell what effect this'll have on the rate outlook? Here's HSBC.

Pharma @XYZed that's bad (worse) news for Danske. The line about sanctions in the statement is a red herring, as the laundering regulations are separate.
chad_john Hi, anything on The Mission Marketing? Only for the incredible use of the word 'frabjously' in their update today.
BE11:33am

[N]ot all the increase in inflation this month necessarily points to a stronger underlying outlook. Interestingly, the more pronounced price increases were in categories that might have seen strong demand as a result of hot weather over the summer (clothing, for example). Indeed, there has been evidence of strong, weather-related, demand in the recent retail sales data. More generally, transport fares and clothing prices can be volatile on a month-by-month basis, so some of the August spike might prove temporary.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

But of course, there is a risk that a more persistent underlying inflation uplift is brewing. The unemployment rate now stands at 4.0%, a fresh 43-year low. And the July data saw a rare upside surprise to wages, with regular pay growth rising from 2.7% to 2.9% 3m/yr

chad_john (and also I hold and very happily today too)
BE11:34am

It is too early to tell which of these two stories played a biggest role in the August data. In order to be more convinced that domestically generated inflation is really taking off, we would probably need to see more sustained gains in services inflation, which remains relatively subdued (Chart 2). To the extent that this continues, and given the growth headwinds facing the UK economy (see Conscious Uncoupling: Four reasons why the BoE won't follow the Fed, 19 September), we do not expect any Bank Rate rises through this year and next.

Markkus Anything on Kingfisher?
BE11:35am

MOST disagrees.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

With growth running above trend, pay picking up and now inflation moving further above target, we expect a more hawkish tone from the MPC. We expect the next hike when the way forward on Brexit is clear, likely in May-19, although possibly as early as Feb-19.

XYZed @ Phaarrrma: I don't think they get fined by US as no US regulated entities themelves. But if they fail to co-operate with US, the US can put them out of business by prohibiting correspondent banks from clearing $ on their behalf (this effectively happened with Wegelin in Switz)
undefined

anonymous254 @ Airborne, many thanks. Helpful and surprising! Naively thought that beyond P&L, that it would have shown up somewhere in the internal reporting of parent that your customers of some branches were holding vast deposits of cash. Surely a balance sheet issue. In the same way as if the branch office was writing loans?
Pharma @XYZed interesting, thanks

Yeah, okay, Kingfisher.

BE11:42am

We would anticipate full year consensus forecasts fall by a further c£20m
today. According to the Company's website (which we consider the most accurate source of consensus data on Kingfisher, given that it has various definitions of profitability) consensus is currently expecting FY 2018/19 Pre Tax Profit of £632m (equating to 21.6p of EPS)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Kingfisher is trading on 10.6x Cal 2019 earnings, 5.4x EBITDA with a 4.7% Dividend Yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 11.8x, 8.0x and 4.9% respectively.

BE11:43am

And JP Morgan Caz.

Penny KGF - last week's Barrons has a positive article on US home improvement retailers.
Airborne Cigar @anon254 - you'd think, and to be fair, more of an issue with foreign subsidiaries than foreign branches. However, if the deposits turnover rapidly enough, it wouldn't show in the summary accounts. My experience here is in the complete inadequacy of accounting data for risk analysis and reporting and consequent issues if that's all the data that's available.
BE11:43am

Overall, management’s tone throughout the statement was, in our
view, fairly weak. In addition to a mixed outlook in key markets, it comments that “the environment is making our task more difficult than expected” and also that “the ongoing high levels of transformation activity…have continued to have an impact on the business”. It has, however, reiterated ONE plan targets and also reiterated that it expects the FY 19 gross margin, post Clearance, to be up yoy (although we remain somewhat sceptical on this.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

And Goldman.

BE11:44am

We expect FY19 company-compiled consensus underlying PBT
of £764mn to reduce by c.2.5% to £745m (-5.5% yoy), reflecting weaker-than-expected performance in Russia/Romania and current challenges in France.

BE11:44am

Our DCF-derived 12-month PT is 385p. Kingfisher currently trades at c.6.5x CY19E EV/EBIT, below its long-term average of c.9.3x EV/EBIT, in our view reflecting concerns on the near-term earnings outlook and execution of the One Kingfisher strategy. We are Buy rated on Kingfisher.

GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,487, up 0.4 (+0.03%), High: 1,500, Low: 1,479, Volume: 1.60m
BE11:51am

Here's Credit Suisse from the back of last month.

BE11:51am

Nestlé’s existing business stands to benefit the most from GSK’s
India business. Nestlé’s revenues will jump ~40% and give major scale
advantages in distribution. Nestlé’s scale of procurement of media and raw
materials will also jump meaningfully. HUL and ITC can add a lot of value to GSK through improved cost efficiencies and scale of distribution. However GSK does not materially add value to HUL or ITC’s existing business.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

In the case of Nestlé or Unilever, it is likely that the parent will buy the
stake and then merge with the subsidiary; this could be significantly
EPS accretive. If either Nestlé or Unilever is the buyer, there is a high
probability that the stake in GSK Consumer India will be acquired by the
parent company and then there will be a merger with the Indian subsidiary. This will help the parent up its stake in the Indian listed subsidiary, which has been a strategic intent. This could be highly EPS accretive, especially for Nestlé India, as the stock will be used to acquire a lower P/E business.

anonymous254 @AC, just would have thought this sort of thing is the only thing a chief risk officer would be on the look out for (i.e. one of their main tasks). But guess the point you're making is that in reality they may not want to find this sort of thing or ask too many questions. Looking now they've been through a few chief risk officers in the period - but maybe that's normal.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The Chatteris visit will bring to an end a period of growing speculation about Jack's, its origins, purpose, scope and maybe strategic relevance to Tesco UK and the wider Group. Jack's is born amidst ongoing reset work by Tesco of its supply chain and offer, notably around exclusive brands, building upon the farm brands already introduced across the estate. Where will any Jack's private label fit into the Tesco product portfolio?

Airborne Cigar @BE - What on earth are city slickers being sent to Chatteris for? Whitemoor jail?
BE11:56am

Chatteris " has been symbolic of Tesco's travails in recent years,
culminating in a store that management did not have the confidence to open as a supermarket, subsequently being mothballed and sub-divided," he says.

BE11:56am

Additionally, we shall be interested to see if Jack's rests within a wider perhaps more strategic context, so the relationship between this new fascia and Tesco's stores - there has been much written about Jack's taking up residence at c60 ex-Metro outlets with a further thirty to close - the core value credentials of Tesco UK, perhaps incorporating some of the good work undertaken in Ireland (e.g. 'The 800 - you won't pay more') and if Jack's could be exported to say Central Europe.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Furthermore, the relationship of Tesco exclusive brands and, indeed, Jack's, to Booker as a distributor and supplier to the new kid on the block? Ahead of reaching Chatteris, there are, therefore, plenty of questions to bat about.

estrangedcapitalist buying cannabis stocks
BBOC Jack's will have 19 branches - Aldi + Lidl have over 1,300...!
Pharma @Tom, it's not that really. Lots of similar products are sold. It's the fact that the "local" versions could contain just about anything, as there are no reliable testing mechanisms. The originals are sold, and trusted.
BE11:57am

Questions, then, but not answers. Similar from HSBC.

BE11:57am

· Is the squeeze worth the juice? What is the long-term potential and will it ever "move the dial" and be material to the investment case? How much investment will be required before this reaches critical mass? Will it impact the margin recovery and cash flow expectations? Is it a management distraction?

· Is it a distraction to the investment case? The risk is that this venture is being conducted in a glare of publicity, will get a disproportionate amount of attention and may be a distraction to the improving investment case at key time.

· Discount formats have failed for others, why will this succeed? Asda has failed twice with a discount chain, Sainsbury failed recently with a Netto JV and Tesco itself had a discount chain called "Victor Value". Why is this different?

· What will the price position be? Tesco already has an exclusive range that undercuts the discounters and it has been building awareness of this range recently with press advertising. We do not know if these products will be available in Jack's, but it would be reasonable if they were. We believe it would be a mistake to sell the same products in Tesco at a different price in Jack's.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

On the positive side, Tesco has Booker's experience in running discount format (Family Shopper) and it has a range of products to go in the store (exclusive brands such as Farm Brands, Stockwell & Co). We see minimal risk and with its momentum and confidence, why not experiment with a new channel? The constituent parts are already in place - Tesco has the range, the property (and property skills) and management. It could be seen as a distraction to the core investment case of margin recovery, cash generation and the re-establishing of Tesco as a good market leader. We will report back post Wednesday's trip.

Airborne Cigar @BE - I believe that store changed hands between owner at least twice between building and commissioning. Or so local gossip had it. (Someone in my family was working in the town at the time.)
Tom Dalgleish @Pharma same as China in that regard. How those countries would soar if only they could trust themselves
BE11:58am

One idea here is that Jacks is an experiment to roll out across Europe rather than a UK- targeted thing.

BE11:58am

Poland's been mentioned.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

What's not been mentioned is cost. The cash going into this seems pretty small in a group context.
